title: How to Clean Grease Stains on Leather

steps.title: Assemble your ingredients.
steps.content: Assemble your ingredients. If you've just spilled some butter or your boots or gotten bacon grease on the couch, it's best to leap into action right away. If you catch it quick enough, all you need to clean your leather item is: A microfiber cloth Talcum powder

steps.title: Dab with the grease as fast as possible with the cloth.
steps.content: Dab with the grease as fast as possible with the cloth. Gently blot at the grease stain, trying to absorb as much of it as possible as quickly as possible. The trouble with cleaning leather is that it tends to absorb liquid, especially grease, making it difficult to clean topically once it's been absorbed. Avoid scrubbing the leather. This can damage the fine grains of the leather, making the stain worse. Blot gently and use some kind of lint-free microfiber cloth.

steps.title: Find the grain of the leather.
steps.content: Find the grain of the leather. Just like wood, leather has a direction of texture. You'll have more success in applying any cleaner if you apply it along the lie, as opposed to across it. In other words, any time you wipe or blot at the leather, you want to do it with the grain. If you're having trouble finding the grain, try to work from the "outside" of the stain in to the center. At the very least, you'll be able to shrink the stain this way. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Spread talcum powder on the item.
steps.content: Spread talcum powder on the item. [2] X Research source Use regular household baby powder to soak up the grease. Be liberal with your application of the powder. It works particularly well at drawing the grease out without damaging the leather because it's more absorbent than the leather is, as long as you get there in time. Let the powder sit overnight, or at least several hours to do its work.

steps.title: Gently brush the talcum powder off the item.
steps.content: Gently brush the talcum powder off the item. [3] X Research source Using a cloth, gently brush off the talcum powder. Be careful not to scrub the powder back into the leather, working the grease back out.

steps.title: Assemble your ingredients.
steps.content: Assemble your ingredients. One particularly effective method of cleaning grease from smaller items is to use a bit of dish soap and distilled water to create a lather and clean the item. You'll need a couple of clean micro-fiber cloths, the soap, and water. [4] X Research source Consider using a spray bottle to make the job easier. You can use mild dishwashing soap and warm water to wash leather. It is better not to use vinegar because it can deepen stains affected by acidity.

steps.title: Apply the detergent.
steps.content: Apply the detergent. Dip the cloth into the liquid detergent. Dab the patch test area with the cloth, being gentle to work with the grain of the leather. You can make a mixture in a cup, dampen a microfiber cloth with the solution, and then wipe down the leather.

steps.title: Soak the leather with the distilled water.
steps.content: Soak the leather with the distilled water. Use your clean fingers to rub the patch test area until you work up a gentle lather. Apply more water as needed to clean the stain.

steps.title: Blot dry with a clean cloth.
steps.content: Blot dry with a clean cloth. [5] X Research source Allow the piece to dry fully before attempting to clean again. You might have to attempt several applications before the stain is shrunken significantly or completely removed from the item. Give it time to dry before attempting to clean it again.

steps.title: Assemble your ingredients.
steps.content: Assemble your ingredients. To create a simple and effective homemade leather cleaning solution, you'll just need the basic ingredients to make a loaf of bread: 3/8 cup of distilled water 1/8 cup of sea salt 1/2 teaspoon white flour 1 tablespoon baking soda

steps.title: Mix the ingredients thoroughly in a bowl.
steps.content: Mix the ingredients thoroughly in a bowl. Use a spoon or fork and work your salt water, flour, and baking soda into a kind of a paste. This is highly effective in gently lifting grease from leather without affecting the leather grains of your item. Alternatively, you can try a mixture

steps.title: Do a patch test.
steps.content: Do a patch test. Find a less visible spot on your item to "patch test" the cleaning solution of choice. If your leather is dyed in any way, any kind of cleaner can affect the color, so pick an out-of-the-way patch to test it on.

steps.title: Dip the cloth into the pasty mixture and dab the test area.
steps.content: Dip the cloth into the pasty mixture and dab the test area. Use a small amount of the mixture on the cloth and be extremely gentle. You want to use the same basic principle as the quick-fix method, gently dabbing and letting the cleaner do the work. Don't make it worse by scrubbing.

steps.title: Pat the area dry with another cloth.
steps.content: Pat the area dry with another cloth. Be gentle and allow the area to dry completely before attempting to clean again. It might take several applications to completely eradicate the stain, or shrink it considerably, but allow the leather time to rejuvenate before you clean it again.

steps.title: Try alternatives.
steps.content: Try alternatives. There are many different cleaning solution recipes used with varying degrees of success. Try different recipes if you can't get the spot as clean as you'd like. Use the same basic method for cleaning, but try different combinations of natural products you've got on hand. [6] X Research source Some have reported success using: [7] X Research source Equal parts water and white vinegar. Equal parts lemon juice and cream of tartar. One part of vinegar to two parts of linseed oil. [8] X Research source
